Award.AwardTitle: PFI-TT: Development of a visual sensor to non-invasively monitor biodegradable magnesium alloy implants for biomedical applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to understand the biodegradation of magnesium (Mg) alloys used in medical implants and to provide a needed diagnostic sensor for post-surgery evaluation of patients. Mg alloys are increasingly used in biodegradable implants for repairing broken bones and other medical applications because they dissolve after the bone is healed, leaving only the natural bone components. Almost 30% of metal implants such as stainless steel must be removed later due to complications or the need to accommodate a still-growing child. The beneficial aspect of using Mg alloys is that a second surgery is not needed, significantly reducing costs of care, surgery risk, and patient stress. Partnering with a technology commercialization expert, this PFI-TT project will enable development, testing, and optimization of the proposed sensor prototype to monitor the biodegradation of Mg-containing implants in both a laboratory and animal setting, promote education in innovation and entrepreneurship, and engage undergraduate and high school students into educational and research programs. This sensor has commercial potential because it fulfills the unmet need in this growing market for a simple diagnostic test for biodegradation progress that is easily performed in a doctor’s office.

The proposed project aims to develop a sensitive, selective and fast-response hydrogen (H2) sensor in the form of a “Band-Aid” type device for the non-invasive monitoring of biodegradable Mg-containing implants. Commonly available X-ray technology works poorly for Mg alloys, because the density of Mg is so close to that of bone that the Mg implants cannot be easily distinguished from bone by X-ray. Thus, there is a critical need for a method to monitor the biodegradation of Mg alloys. Measurement of the low level of H2 gas from the slowly dissolving Mg permeating through skin for the purpose of monitoring the biodegradation of Mg implants is completely unique. The objective of this application is to optimize the H2 sensor prototype. The central hypothesis is that the H2 sensor will non-invasively cause a color change when exposed to H2 and provide a visual map of H2 levels over an area above the Mg implant. This hypothesis is formulated based on the supporting preliminary data. The underlying rationale is that the researchers will obtain insight into the overall design of the sensor, which is an essential step toward commercialization of the sensor for non-invasive monitoring of biodegradation of Mg-containing implants in patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnesium and its alloys have attracted significant attention for biodegradable implants due to their excellent biocompatibility with human physiology, including mechanical properties compatible with bone. Most importantly, they biodegrade in biological fluids at a rate that can be controlled by forming appropriate alloys. Metals (e.g., stainless steel) are widely used for bone repair such as orthopedic fracture fixation and craniomaxillofacial applications. Almost 30% of implants of this type are removed later because of complications or the need to accommodate a still-growing child. The most beneficial aspect of using Magnesium instead of stainless steel is that a second surgery is not needed to remove a Magnesium implant, significantly reducing costs of care as well as surgery risk and patient stress. Moreover, unlike resorbable plastic implants, the biodegradation product, Magnesium ions, facilitates healing by stimulating the growth of new bone tissue. Magnesium implants are being used on patients in Europe and Asia, and the first Magnesium product was given approval for use in the United States by the FDA.

Understanding biodegradation of Magnesium alloy implants is critical to designing/manufacturing better implants with optimal resorption rates as well as appropriate mechanical properties to withstand relevant biomechanical forces. Monitoring of Magnesium implant resorption is of great importance to determine if a surgical or other intervention is required. Yet it represents a substantial challenge because commonly available, standard X-ray does not work well for Magnesium; the density of Magnesium and its alloys is so close to that of bone that a Magnesium implant cannot be easily distinguished from a bone by standard X-ray. Costly techniques such as CT scans are required to monitor Magnesium biodegradation. Thus, there is a critical need for innovative methods to easily and inexpensively monitor Magnesium biodegradation if biodegradable Magnesium implants are to realize the full potential.

We have previously demonstrated a novel strategy to monitor biodegradation of Magnesium implants non-invasively by measuring hydrogen levels at the skin. In this proposed research, we have developed a kind of visual hydrogen sensor, in the form of a Band Aid-like thin adhesive sensor, that displays color change when exposed to hydrogen. We have evaluated the performance of the hydrogen sensor prototypes under controlled hydrogen flow and conducted a round of animal tests on mice with a Magnesium implant, which have given us first-hand experience with the type of animal testing being performed worldwide by researchers developing biodegradable metals. The results have validated the capability of the hydrogen sensor prototype and paved the way for further animal testing and clinical trial in the next stage of development. Our ultimate goal is to provide a non-invasive, radiation-free, simple and inexpensive hydrogen sensor for point-of-care monitoring of biodegradation of Magnesium implants. It is conceivable that patients could eventually apply the sensor at home, photograph results at a defined time point, and send the images for evaluation without the need of a doctor’s office visit.


Broader Impacts: (1) Benefits to society - The work is expected to provide an important positive impact on the non-invasive monitoring of biodegradable metal implants. (2) Promoting education and leadership development in innovation and entrepreneurship - The project has allowed the participating postdoc and student(s) to learn skills different from the typical academic settings. (3) Inclusion and diversity in STEM participation. The proposed research also highlights the partnership between a public university and an entrepreneur.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2024
Modified by: Peng Zhang
